Author: Pyrrho of Elis
René Descartes
David Hume
Antagonist: The assumption that certain knowledge is attainable without doubt.
Content: Skepticism is a philosophical position that questions whether we can truly know anything with absolute certainty. It challenges assumptions about reality, perception, and belief, pushing us to reconsider how knowledge is acquired and whether our perceptions can be trusted. One of the earliest skeptics, Pyrrho of Elis, argued that humans should suspend judgment on all matters, as certainty is unattainable. Later, René Descartes introduced radical skepticism, doubting even the existence of the external world through his thought experiment of an evil demon deceiving us into a false reality. His only unshakable truth was 'Cogito, ergo sum'—I think, therefore I am—since even doubting proved the existence of a conscious thinker. Skepticism takes many forms: empirical skepticism questions the reliability of the senses, moral skepticism challenges the idea of objective moral truths, and religious skepticism critically examines claims about gods, miracles, and the supernatural, often requiring empirical evidence before acceptance. While skepticism encourages critical thinking, logical consistency, and a demand for evidence, extreme skepticism can lead to solipsism—the belief that only one's own mind is certain to exist—making engagement with reality difficult. David Hume advocated for moderate skepticism, arguing that while certainty is impossible, rational beliefs can be formed based on probability and experience. This balance between doubt and practicality allows for questioning assumptions while still engaging with the world. In modern times, skepticism remains central to debates on misinformation, scientific theories, and conspiracy beliefs, reminding us that questioning is essential but must be tempered by acting on reasonable evidence, even without absolute certainty.
